chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text: In this problem, we will use the assumption that there are only corporate taxes in order to derive the formula for cost of equity using the M&M Proposition II.

Net income is defined as:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NI}&=(\text{EBIT}-\text{R}_D \times\text{D})\times(1-\text{T}_C)
\end{aligned}$$

Where,

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NI}&=\text{Net income}\\
\text{EBIT}&=\text{Earnings before interest and tax}\\
\text{R}_D&=\text{Cost of debt}\\
\text{D}&=\text{Debt}\\
\text{T}_C&=\text{Corporate tax rate}
\end{aligned}$$

We can then represent the value of unlevered equity in terms of the value of levered equity, we will them get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{R}_E&=\text{R}_U(\text{V}_L-\text{T}_C\text{D})/\text{E}-[\text{R}_D(\text{D}/\text{E})(1-\text{T}_C)]
\end{aligned}$$

By rearranging and simplifying the variables, we will end up with:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{R}_E&=\text{R}_U(\text{E}+\text{D}-\text{T}_C\text{D})/\text{E}-[\text{R}_D(\text{D}/\text{E})(1-\text{T}_C)]\\[15 pt]
\text{R}_E&=\text{R}_U+(\text{R}_U-\text{R}_D) \times (\text{D}/\text{E}) \times (1-\text{T}_C)
\end{aligned}$$

The final formula brings us back to the M&M Proposition II where only corporate taxes exist.
